Graphical abstract La2Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LNZ6), La1.95Ca0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LCNZ6), La1.95Sr0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LSNZ6) catalysts were investigated for DRM reaction to determine the effect of Sr- and Ca- substitution at the La site in Ni substituted Lanthanum Zirconate pyrochlore. XRD confirmed the formation of the pyrochlore phase with Ni substitution. Additionally, NiO and perovskite phases of Ni were detected. XANES and XRD confirmed the reduction of Ni to active Ni0 phase in reduced and spent catalysts. LSNZ6 turned out to be the most active DRM catalyst because of the higher surface Ni content, smaller particle size and high dispersion achieved as observed from XPS, XRD, SEM-EDS elemental mapping and TPR. LSNZ6 exhibited better resistance to sintering with negligible Ni size growth compared to LCNZ6 and LNZ6. Coke formation was inevitable and LSNZ6 showed more carbon formation which suggests carbon deposition correlated directly with activity. However, it had negligible impact on the activity and stability of the catalysts. Keywords Dry reforming of methane Ni catalysts Pyrochlore Syngas Oxygen vacancies CO2 conversion 1 Introduction Natural gas supply increased drastically in United States due to the “shale gas revolution”. Methane, a major component of natural gas, has attracted significant research in recent times [1–4]. Dry Reforming of Methane (DRM) has been extensively studied as one of the potential routes for utilization of methane. DRM is the reaction of CH4 and CO2 to produce syngas (synthesis gas, Eq. (1)) with a H2/CO molar ratio close to 1 [5]. (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 H 2 + 2 C O Δ H º = + 247 k J / m o l , Δ G º = 61770 - 67.32 T Syngas, a mixture of CO and H2, can be used for Fischer Tropsch reaction, synthesis of oxoalcohols and acetic acid [6]. DRM reaction can reduce net emissions of CH4 and CO2 provided the energy used for it is coming from non-hydrocarbon sources like solar, nuclear [7,8]. This is a highly endothermic reaction requiring high temperatures. At such temperatures, a simultaneous occurrence of Reverse Water Gas Shift reaction (RWGS, Eq. (2)) is induced [9]. Due to this, higher CO2 conversion and lower H2/CO values are commonly observed. (2) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ C O + H 2 O Δ H º + 41.2 k J / m o l , Δ G º = - 8545 + 7.84 T Noble metal catalysts have been investigated to show high activity and stability for DRM but are expensive. Transition metal based catalysts, Ni in particular, are active, economical and thus practical options. However, nickel based catalysts are prone to deactivation by carbon deposition [10–12] and sintering [13,14] at high operating temperatures. Carbon deposition occurs mainly due to methane decomposition (Eq. (3)) and/or Boudouard reaction (CO disproportionation reaction, Eq. (4)). Enthalpy of these reactions suggest that Eq. (3) is favored at higher temperatures while Eq. (4) occurs predominantly at lower temperatures [5]. In order to overcome these challenges, more thermally stable and carbon tolerant materials are desirable. (3) C H 4 ↔ C s + 2 H 2 Δ H º = + 75 k J / m o l , Δ G º = - 2190 - 26.45 T (4) 2 C O ↔ C ( s ) + C O 2 Δ H º = - 171 k J / m o l , Δ G º = - 39810 + 40.87 T Different strategies have been adopted by researchers to overcome these challenges. Synergistic effects generated by the introduction of a second metal in case of bimetallic Ni catalysts have shown enhanced catalytic properties towards DRM [15–19]. In addition to conventional supported catalysts, active metals incorporated in thermally stable crystalline oxides like perovskites, pyrochlores, hydrotalcites and hexaaluminates were studied for DRM [20–27]. The exsolution process involved in these oxides during the calcination and reduction prior to the DRM reaction produces a metal – support catalyst system with high dispersion of active metal on the surface of the oxide. This promotes a strong interaction of the active metal with the support which plays a key role in minimizing carbon on the catalyst. Pyrochlores are highly crystalline oxides with general formula A2B2O7 where A is a rare-earth element and B is a transition metal. They are typically inactive as bulk materials, however, partial substitution of B site with an active metal cation produces catalytic activity towards DRM. Also, substitutions at A and B sites create oxygen vacancies which improve the oxygen mobility assisting in gasification of surface deposited carbon [28,29]. These materials have excellent thermal and chemical stability at DRM conditions. Ni substituted Lanthanum Zirconate (LZ) pyrochlores previously have shown high activity towards DRM along with simultaneous occurrence of RWGS reaction. However, the catalysts with lower Ni loading (1 & 5 wt %) were prone to deactivation at lower reaction temperatures due to carbon deposition [20,30]. Strontium and Ni- substituted LZ pyrochlores were previously studied by our group but the effect of Ni loading was reported at higher temperatures [21]. Here, we describe a logical study of the stability of the catalysts at comparatively lower reaction temperatures at which carbon deposition is thermodynamically favorable. We are aware of no study of the effect of alkaline earth metal substitution in Ni-substituted pyrochlores in DRM reaction although closely related perovskites have been studied for Sr- and Ca- substitution in La-Ni perovskites which showed enhanced stability towards DRM [31,32]. In this work, we study three different Ni- substituted Lanthanum Zirconate catalysts, designated as LNZ6, LCNZ6 and LSNZ6. LNZ6 is unsubstituted at La site while LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 catalysts have partial Ca- and Sr- substitutions at the La site respectively. Effect of these alkaline earth metal substitutions on the physical, chemical and catalytic properties of the pyrochlore material is explored. All three catalysts have 6% Ni loading and the specific formula for LNZ6, LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 are La2Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d, La1.95Ca0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d, La1.95Sr0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d respectively. Several spectroscopic, microscopic and thermal characterizations have been performed to investigate the catalyst properties and their effect on DRM activity and stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation LZ, LNZ6, LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 pyrochlore catalysts were all prepared by modified Pechini method [33]. Lanthanum Nitrate [La(NO3)3.6H2O)], Strontium Nitrate [Sr(NO3)2], Calcium Nitrate [Ca(NO3)2.xH2O], Nickel Nitrate [Ni(NO3)2.6H2O] and Zirconyl Nitrate [ZrO(NO3)2.xH2O)] were used as metal precursors. Stoichiometric amounts of corresponding nitrate precursors dissolved separately in DI water were mixed together in a beaker and stirred continuously. An aqueous citric acid (CA) solution with CA: metal ion ratio of 1.2:1 was added to the metal solution as a complexing agent and stirred continuously. The resulting solution was stirred and heated to 70 °C to allow metal complexation. At this temperature, a polymerizing agent ethylene glycol (EG) was added to the solution at EG:CA molar ratio of 1:1. The solution was stirred continuously until the water was driven off and a viscous gel remained. The gel was then heated to 130 °C to remove the nitrates and promote polyesterification reaction. The resulting amorphous powder was dried overnight at 130 °C and then calcined at 1000 °C for 4 h resulting in a pyrochlore catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 BET surface area Surface area of the catalysts was determined by Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) analysis in an Altamira AMI-200 catalyst characterization system using N2 monolayer adsorption. Prior to the analysis, catalyst samples were degassed in an inert gas at 473 K for about 30 min as a pretreatment process. A three-point BET with 10 %, 20 % and 30 % N2/Ar was used to determine the specific surface area of the catalyst. 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD analysis of the catalyst samples were performed in a PANAnalytical EMPYREAN diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54 Å) from 20° to 80° at a step size of 0.026°/sec and 137.19 s step time. The Scherrer equation was used for determination of crystallite size. 2.2.3 X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES) Nickel K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements were performed at the electron storage ring of J. Bennett Johnston, Sr. Center for Advanced Microstructures and Devices (CAMD), Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, Louisiana. The measurements were made at the WDCM 2.0 beamline, equipped with a Si-111 channel-cut monochromator. The beamline was calibrated with a standard nickel foil (E0 = 8333 eV) which was later maintained between the second and third ion chambers during measurement as a reference. The samples were prepared by smearing a very thin layer on a Kapton™ tape and folding it several times to get the necessary edge jump. All samples were measured in fluorescence mode, with integration time of five seconds. A Ketek™ seven-element silicon drift detector with 560 mm2 effective area was used for fluorescence X-ray measurements. The full width half maximum (FWHM) of the detector at 5.9 keV is 135 eV. Data analysis was performed with Athena. 2.2.4 X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS measurements were conducted at the endstation of the 5-meter toroidal grating monochromator (5m-TGM) beamline at the Center for Advanced Microstructures and Devices (CAMD) facility. The endstation is equipped with an Omicron EA125 hemispherical electron energy analyzer with a five-channel detector and dual Mg/Al X-ray source. The powder samples were placed on a carbon tape and the Al anode source (hυ = 1486.6 eV) was used for core level XPS. All high-resolution scans were performed in a constant energy mode with a pass energy of 30 eV. The binding energies in the spectra were calibrated by using the C-1 s core level of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. XPS data analysis was performed using CasaXPS software. 2.2.5 Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) SEM imaging and EDS analysis for the samples was carried out using FEI Quanta 3D FEG FIB/SEM dual beam system interfaced with AMETEK EDAX EDS/EBSD system. A voltage of 5KV and a resolution of 3 μm was used to detect the elemental compositions during the sample analysis. Also, corresponding elemental mapping were collected using the same system. 2.2.6 High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) HRTEM images of the spent catalysts were obtained using JEOL JEM-2011 Scanning TEM at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Imaging was done at different magnification levels to have a detailed analysis of carbon deposited during the reaction. 2.2.7 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy analysis for the spent catalysts was carried out using Renishaw inVia Raman microscope equipment. Spectra was obtained using most common green laser of 532 nm wavelength at 10 mW power and 50 μm slit aperture. 2.2.8 H2 - temperature programmed reduction (H2 - TPR) TPR of the catalysts was performed in an Altamira AMI-200 fixed bed reactor system equipped with a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD). About 100 mg of the corresponding catalyst was weighed, loaded and packed between quartz wool plugs in 6 mm ID quartz tube for each run. A thermocouple, inserted touching the bed of the catalyst, is used to control the sample bed temperature. Prior to the reduction process, a Temperature Programmed Oxidation (TPO) was carried out to oxidize any leftover residual carbon species from the synthesis. For this, the catalyst was oxidized by increasing the temperature from ambient to 800 °C under the flow of 10 %O2/He at a steady rate of 10 °C/min. After this step, the catalyst was cooled down to ambient temperature in the flow of Argon. Then, the TPR was performed by ramping the temperature up to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under the flow of 5%H2/Ar using a flow rate of 40 mL/min. TCD signal during this process was measured and saved which is used to obtain qualitative and quantitative information regarding the reducibility of the catalysts. Amount of H2 consumed during TPR was calibrated using a known standard of silver oxide (Ag2O). 2.3 Catalyst behaviour towards DRM - Activity and stability test DRM activity runs were performed in the same Altamira AMI-200 catalyst characterization system mounted with a fixed bed quartz U-tube reactor as in TPR. 100 mg sample of the catalyst was used for each run and the temperature of the catalyst bed was controlled using a thermocouple. Before the actual DRM reaction, the catalyst was subjected to a TPO- TPR cycle. TPO removes any residual carbon leftover in the catalyst from synthesis process while TPR activates the catalyst by reducing the oxide form of Ni to the metallic form, which is believed to be the active phase in DRM. During both the temperature programmed processes, the catalyst reaches a maximum temperature of 800 °C. After the TPR, the catalyst was continued to reduce at the same temperature of 800 °C for about 10 min and then degassed under the flow of Ar for about 30 min bringing the temperature to the desired reaction temperature, which is 800 °C. After this step, the reactant mixture of 10 %CH4/He and 10 %CO2/He was introduced into the reactor at a molar ratio of 1:1 and Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) of 18 Lh−1g.cat−1. During the reaction, the product stream was continuously monitored using an AMETEK mass spectrometer interfaced with the reactor system. Reactant conversions, product yields and H2/CO ratios were calculated using the formulae used in our previous study on DRM [21]. After the reactions, the catalysts were taken out and other characterizations were performed. TPO was performed on the spent catalysts to analyse the coke deposited during the reactions. During TPO, the temperature was ramped to 950 °C at a steady rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of 15 mL/min 10 %O2/He and the CO2 signal was recorded using the mass spectrometer. Additionally, a DRM reaction at 825 °C was carried out on LSNZ6 catalyst to analyse the type and source of carbon formed in these catalysts (activity and stability results are discussed in section S4 of Supplementary Material). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fresh and reduced catalyst characterizations 3.1.1 BET BET surface area results are shown in Table 1 . Ni substitution in the catalyst lowered the surface area of the materials. Increase in oxygen vacancies by the introduction of Ca- and Sr- at La site tend to further reduce the surface area. However, greater surface area of LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 could be due to the presence of perovskite phase (observed from XRD analysis). 3.1.2 XRD XRD spectra of the fresh catalysts is shown in Fig. 1 a. All the catalyst samples show peaks corresponding to the face centered cubic unit cell Lanthanum Zirconate pyrochlore structure (LZ). The presence of low intensity peaks (331) and (511) confirm that the modified Pechini method of catalyst preparation produces pyrochlore structure instead of fluorite phase which is also typical for these materials [30,34,35]. Ca and Sr substituted catalysts (LCNZ6 and LSNZ6) show significant peaks of La2NiZrO6, a rhombohedral perovskite phase, which are not detected in LNZ6. Formation of a perovskite phase in substituted pyrochlores was also observed by Haynes et al. [28], and le Saché et al. [30]. Peaks at 31.45°, 45.05°, 65.53° and 74.55° 2θ values in Fig. 1 a correspond to La2NiZrO6 phase. On the other hand, LNZ6 spectra shows a small peak at 32.25° which correlates to a perovskite phase which could either be rhombohedral LaNiO3 or tetragonal La2NiO4. Most intense peak of this perovskite phase in LNZ6 coincides with the (400) peak of pyrochlore phase. Additionally, (200) and (220) peaks of NiO phase, at 2θ values of 43.4° and 63.05° respectively, were observed in all the fresh catalysts. This (200) peak of NiO coincides with the low intensity (511) peak of the pyrochlore. Fig. 1 b shows inset plot of (222) peak of pyrochlore phase. Shift in the peak towards lower 2θ values in the substituted pyrochlores confirm that at least a portion of Ni is occupying the pyrochlore structure. Also, Ca and Sr substitution in the pyrochlore structure is confirmed by the shift of (222) peak towards higher 2θ values in LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 compared to LNZ6. However, formation of perovskite phases and NiO phases in the catalysts suggest the low solubility of Ni in the pyrochlore structure. Lattice constant values are reported in Table 1. Several previous studies on DRM confirmed that the metallic Ni supported on the oxide catalyst is responsible for the reaction [5,12,36,37]. Hence, all the catalysts were reduced under 10 %H2/Ar by performing a TPR before the DRM activity runs to activate the catalyst. XRD plots of reduced samples are shown in Figs. 2–4 . (220) peak of NiO disappears completely while the peak at 43.4° still exists in the reduced samples. This peak is believed to be to (511) peak of pyrochlore phase, suggesting that most of the NiO is reduced to Ni° with its most intense peak centered at 44.6° 2θ. The particle sizes of Ni in the reduced catalysts are included in the Table 1. A shift in the (222) peak of pyrochlore phase towards higher 2θ values observed in reduced samples of all the catalysts (shift for LSNZ6 is shown in Fig. S1 of Supplementary Material) suggests that the Ni from the pyrochlore structure is reduced and exsolved out during the reduction pre-treatment process. Also, a slight decrease in intensity of La2NiZrO6 perovskite phase in reduced samples is seen (an inset is shown for LSNZ6 in Fig. S2 of Supplementary Material). This is due to the reduction of the perovskite phase into Ni°, La2O3 and ZrO2. XRD does not detect ZrO2 phase in reduced samples suggesting that it is confined only to the surface layers. 3.1.3 XANES XANES analysis provided information about oxidation and coordination state of Ni in the catalysts. The XANES spectra of Ni K-edge region for the fresh catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . NiO and Ni0 (foil) are used as reference materials and their Ni K-edge plots are also included. All the fresh catalyst plots resemble NiO suggesting most of the Ni is primarily in +2 oxidation state in an oxide environment. This oxide environment includes pyrochlore and perovskite phases also. K edge energy values are determined from the derivative plots of XANES spectra (Fig. 6 ). These values are reported in Table 2 are found to be slightly higher than NiO suggesting stronger coordination environment for Ni coming from perovskite and pyrochlore structures. Ni K-edge energy values of La2NiO4 and LaNiO3 reported by Woolley et al. [38], are also included in the table. As Ni is most likely to be present in +2 coordination state (observed from the XANES plots), it suggests that the perovskite phase present in fresh LNZ6 catalyst is La2NiO4 but not LaNiO3 (which has Ni in +3 oxidation state). Ni K-edge value of LNZ6 also supports this claim. Fig. S3 of Supplementary Material shows the Ni K-edge XANES plots of the catalysts after reduction (TPR pre-treatment step for DRM reaction) compared to fresh catalysts. A significant decrease in the white line intensities was detected in reduced samples which confirms the formation of Ni0. This is also confirmed from the derivative plots (shown in Fig. 7 ) showing the presence of mixture of oxide and metallic phases of Ni. Due to reduction, the intensity of first derivative peak at ∼8333ev corresponding to Ni0 phase increased in all the catalysts. Also, a small shift in the peak corresponding to Ni+2 phase towards higher energy values is observed in LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 indicating that most of the unreduced Ni is from the perovskite phase. Ni+2 present in much stronger coordination environment of perovskite has higher K-edge energy value. LNZ6 has much lower white line peak intensity than LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 (shown in Fig. S4 of Supplementary Material) due to the presence of greater amount of bulk metallic Ni in the reduced sample. Lower reducibility of LSNZ6 and LCNZ6 is due to the presence of Ni in more stable La2NiZrO6 perovskite phase. This data obtained from XANES validates the observations made from XRD. 3.1.4 XPS XPS data for the fresh catalysts is presented in Fig. 8 . Binding energies and peak structures of La 3d, Zr 3d and Ni 3p regions are similar for all the catalysts. Therefore, plots for only LSNZ6 are shown here. Additionally, O1s region scan for all the three catalysts is also presented. La 3d has a characteristic spin orbit split into 3d3/2 and 3d5/2. In our work, we analysed only La 3d5/2 zone, both quantitatively and qualitatively, because of the overlap of La 3d3/2 region with the 2p3/2 region of Ni. This 3d5/2 region further shows a doublet splitting with peaks at ∼838.4ev and ∼834.6ev. The difference in the binding energies between this doublet of 3d5/2 region in all the catalysts is ∼3.8ev [39]. This shows majority of La on the surface in a +3 oxidation state in the oxide environment, as expected. Zr 3d shows the peaks corresponding to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 at 181.4ev and 183.7ev which correspond to a +4 oxidation state of Zr [39,40]. Ni 3p scan shows most of the Ni in +2 oxidation state, however, a small amount of +3 Ni is present on the surface which could be due to the adsorbed oxygen at surface oxygen vacancies. XPS information of Sr and Ca is difficult to obtain because of their very low loading. O1 s region for all the catalysts is shown in Fig. 8 d. All the plots show 3 major peaks. Peak centered at ∼529.5ev corresponds to lattice oxygen in the mixed oxide structures while the peaks at ∼531.5ev and ∼532.6ev correspond to oxygen vacancies and adsorbed oxygen on the surface [41]. Additionally a small peak at ∼528ev is visible which is due to oxygen from La2O3 on the surface. La2O3 has an unusually low O1 s binding energy than other typical metal oxides [42]. Small quantity of La2O3 is confirmed to be present on the surface which is not detected in XRD as this phase is confined only to the surface. It is clearly seen that the oxygen vacancy peak is more intense in LSNZ6. Also, peak area ratio of oxygen vacancies to lattice oxygen in LNZ6, LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 are found to be 0.32, 0.25 and 0.48. These values confirm the presence of more oxygen vacancies on the surface of LSNZ6. Unusually lower amount of surface oxygen vacancies observed in LCNZ6 could be due to the shielding of the vacancies by surface species of ZrO2, NiO and La2O3. 3.1.5 SEM-EDS SEM-EDS analysis along with elemental mapping was performed on all the catalysts and the data obtained is qualitatively similar, thus, here we discuss only the qualitative information of LSNZ6. However, the elemental composition data obtained from the analysis is reported for all the catalysts in Table 3 . SEM image along with corresponding elemental mapping images and EDS spectra of LSNZ6 are shown in Fig. 9 . La Lα, Sr Lα, Ni Kα, Zr Lα and O Kα peaks were clearly determined from the EDS spectra. SEM image shows that the surface of the catalyst is decorated with clusters of particles with different sizes. Corresponding elemental mapping image shows that these clusters are made of ZrO2. Circled regions in the mapping image of Fig. 9 c have dense pink colour which correspond to Zr element. This confirms the enrichment of Zr on the surface which is strongly believed to be ZrO2 exsolved out of the bulk due to the formation of Lanthanum rich perovskite phase. Elemental mapping images of individual elements (Fig. S5 of Supplementary Material) show that La and Ni are homogeneously dispersed on the surface with some dark spots evident due to the ZrO2 coverage over them. Zr rich regions are reconfirmed from the EDS mapping image of Zr with the clusters showing brighter pink colour. XPS derived surface chemical composition compared to the bulk composition obtained from SEM-EDS is presented in Table 3. Ni is present more in the bulk phases than on the surface in all the catalysts. LCNZ6 has comparatively lesser Ni content on the surface. This could be due to sintering of Ni forming larger particles during calcination. Also, all the catalysts showed higher La/Zr ratio in the bulk than the surface confirming the presence of La rich perovskite phases. EDS has stronger penetrating depth (1−10 μm) than XPS (5−10 nm) [36]. Thus, EDS is more bulk analysis whereas XPS is surface analysis. However, SEM-EDS does not provide overall bulk elemental composition. 3.1.6 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) TPR analysis was performed on the fresh, calcined catalysts to study the reducibility of active metal, Ni. Fig. 10 shows the hydrogen TPR profiles of LNZ6, LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 fresh catalysts. All the three catalysts show two major peaks, one between 450 °C–500 °C and the other over 580 °C. Low temperature peak of reduction for these catalysts is due to the reduction of NiO exsolved from the pyrochlore structure (due to low solubility of Ni in pyrochlore structure) during the calcination process. This peak is centered at 482 °C for LNZ6 while the addition of Sr and Ca at La site shifted this peak to slightly lower temperatures, 475 °C and 453 °C respectively. This is due to the increase in oxygen vacancies of LSNZ6 and LCNZ6 with the substitution at La site. Surface oxygen vacancies enhance the activation of hydrogen on the surface [43–45]. Adsorbed oxygen or capping oxygen associated with the oxygen vacancies activates the hydrogen molecule on the surface which helps in reducing the adjacent NiO molecules. Further, low reducibility temperature of LCNZ6 can be attributed to larger particle size of NiO in LCNZ6 (observed from XRD presented in Table 1). Higher temperature peaks, 640 °C and 648 °C in LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 respectively are due to the reduction of Ni in the La2NiZrO6 perovskite phase [28,30]. This Ni has stronger interaction with the mixed oxide support. Also, there is a similar high temperature peak in case of LNZ6 which is centered at 593 °C. This is due to the reduction of Ni in the perovskite phase La2NiO4 which was also detected XRD and XAS. However, the high intensity of this peak suggests that there is a significant quantity of NiO reduced at this temperature which is strongly interacting with the mixed oxide support. Further, a low temperature peak is detected in TPR plots of all the catalysts which is due to the reduction of larger NiO particles weakly interacting with the support. This peak is centered at 276 °C, 281 °C and 300 °C for LNZ6, LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 respectively showing LNZ6 has largest particle size in this reduction region. However, considering all the peak positions and the interaction strengths with the supports from the TPR plots, it can be observed that LSNZ6 has lower particle size than other catalysts which is in accordance with XRD. Amount of H2 intake during the reduction of the catalysts is reported in Table 3. These values are in accordance with the XAS data which confirms the greater reducibility Ni in LNZ6. 3.2 Catalyst behaviour towards DRM – activity and stability test LNZ6, LCNZ6 and LSNZ6 catalysts are tested for DRM reaction at 800 °C temperature, 18 Lh−1gcat−1 GHSV and ambient pressure. Catalytic behaviour in terms of reactant conversions is presented in Figs. 11 and 12 . Equilibrium conversions of CH4 and CO2 at 800 °C are included in the plots for reference. These plots also provide the information about stability of the catalysts during 100 h reaction period. Also, the numerical values of the reactant conversions, product selectivity and H2/CO are tabulated and shown in Table 4 . CO2 conversion is higher than CH4 conversion for all the catalysts. This suggests the simultaneous occurrence of “Reverse Water Gas Shift (RWGS)” reaction. Also, the presence of oxygen vacancies is expected to enhance CO2 dissociation rate which could also be a reason for the higher conversion values of CO2 [20,21]. LSNZ6 is the most active catalyst with CO2 and CH4 initial conversions of 81 % and 45 % respectively. A slightly lower activity is shown by LNZ6 catalyst with CO2 and CH4 conversions of 54 % and 17 % respectively initially. LCNZ6 is the least active catalyst producing about 4% and 34 % CO2 conversion respectively. A comparison study of Sr and Ca substituted La-Ni-Al perovskite catalysts by Khalesi et al. [31] also showed better activity in case of Sr substituted catalysts. DRM was also studied on unsubstituted Lanthanum Zirconate (LZ) pyrochlore and no activity was observed. This confirms that Ni is the active component for this reaction. The active phase of Ni is exsolved Ni particles in reduced form supported on the mixed oxide support. Higher activity of LSNZ6 catalyst is attributed to the higher surface content of Ni and lower Ni particle size as observed from XPS and XRD respectively. Though the particle sizes if Ni in LSNZ6 and LNZ6 are comparable, the higher surface oxygen vacancy percentage in LSNZ6 activates CH4 more favourably on the surface of LSNZ6 [32]. This is in accordance with the literature that the activation of CH4 takes place at the interface of active metal and the support. LCNZ6 shows poor activity due to lower Ni surface content and comparatively larger particle size of active metal covering the surface. Due to larger particle size, there seems to be lesser interaction area between Ni and the mixed oxide support available for CH4 activation. Also, greater surface coverage of La2O3 and ZrO2 in LCNZ6 could be shielding the active Ni sites further limiting the activity. An increase in the CH4 conversion observed during the 100 h run in LNZ6 suggests the formation of active sites during the reaction. Araujo et al. [46] also observed the formation of active sites during the reaction. Reduction of perovskite phase during the reaction provides with more surface active sites. This increase in activity is also observed in the other two catalysts but it seems to be very small because of the greater stability of La2NiZrO6 phase. Higher temperatures of operation enhance the reduction of this perovskite phase as observed in our previous study [21]. Due to greater methane activity in LSNZ6, H2/CO ratio produced is higher than the other two catalysts. All the three catalysts show excellent stability with no deactivation reported during 100 h DRM runs. 3.3 Post reaction catalyst characterizations 3.3.1 XRD Spent catalysts after the 100 h reactions are characterized for XRD to determine any structural changes. Fig. 2–4 shows the XRD plots of spent catalysts compared to their reduced and fresh samples. Although no significant differences exist between the XRD spectra of reduced and spent samples, a slight increase in Ni° peak at 44.6° during the reaction is observed. This increase is clearly visible for LNZ6, shown in Fig. 13 . La2Zr2O7 peaks are still present intact at similar intensities in all the spent catalysts, which shows that the pyrochlore structure is highly stable at DRM conditions. Also, the La2NiZrO6 perovskite phase of LSNZ6 and LCNZ6 is stable, contrary to our previous study [21]. This could be due to lower operating temperature in current study. Ni crystal growth in LSNZ6 is lesser than LCNZ6 and LNZ6 (values tabulated in Table 1). Presence of more surface oxygen vacancies in LSNZ6 prevents the Ni particles from sintering [47]. Oxygen vacancies/defects increase the metal-support adhesion preventing the Ni clusters to agglomerate. Lower surface oxygen vacancy of LCNZ6 is due to the higher surface coverage of ZrO2. However, the crystal growth in LNZ6 and LCNZ6 is very small suggesting the stability of our catalysts. This sintering resistant characteristic of our catalysts is due to the strong interaction of highly dispersed Ni particles with the mixed oxide support. 3.3.2 XANES In addition to XRD, XANES was performed on the spent LSNZ6 catalyst (most active catalyst) to determine the behaviour of Ni during the reaction. XANES spectra and the derivative plots of Ni K-edge region for fresh, reduced and spent LSNZ6 are plotted in Figs. 14 and 15 . Decrease in the white line intensity from the fresh to reduced catalyst and further to spent catalyst is a clear indication of transformation of Ni+2 to Ni0. This supports our claim from XRD that Ni from pyrochlore and perovskite phases is exsolved and reduced during the reaction. The first derivative plots of XANES spectra reconfirms the formation of Ni0. Obvious increase in derivative peak at ∼8333ev (corresponding to Ni0) with simultaneous decrease in the peak at ∼8345ev is evident in the spent LSNZ6 compared to the reduced sample. This reduction and exsolution of Ni from the mixed oxide structure observed during the course of reaction is responsible for a slight increase in the methane conversion. 3.3.3 Coke analysis Even though the catalyst is chemically and thermally stable at DRM conditions (Figs. 11 and 12), carbon deposition is inevitable. Fig. 16 shows TPO profiles of all catalysts after 100 h DRM runs at 800 °C and 18 Lh−1gcat−1 GHSV. Additionally, to further analyse the type and source of carbon deposited, a TPO plot of LSNZ6 after 100 h DRM reaction at a higher TOS of 825 °C and 18 Lh−1gcat−1 is shown in Fig. 17 . Higher conversion and selectivity values were observed for LSNZ6 at 825 °C (activity of LSNZ6 at 825 °C is further discussed in section S5 of Supplementary Material). LNZ6 and LCNZ6 show one major peak centered at ∼345 °C which corresponds to amorphous carbon, less refractory than other carbon. LSNZ6 also shows this low temperature peak with similar intensity, but in addition to this peak, a more intense peak centered at ∼520 °C is detected. This peak corresponds to filamentous carbon which is comparatively more resistant towards oxidation. Continuous accumulation of carbon on the catalyst as the reaction proceeds transforms amorphous carbon into denser filamentous form (carbon rich) which further transforms into graphitic carbon or carbon nanotubes (CNT) [37,48,49]. However, quantitative analysis showed that the amount of carbon deposited is very less at 800 °C. High coke resistance in these catalysts is due to the presence of oxygen vacancies promoting better oxygen mobility. As the reaction temperature increases, LSNZ6 shows comparatively large amount of carbon deposition. This suggests that the carbon deposited on the catalyst is mainly due to methane decomposition reaction (Eq. (4)) because this reaction is more favoured at high temperatures [5]. Fig. 17 compares the carbon deposition on LSNZ6 at 800 °C and 825 °C both quantitatively and qualitatively. A peak centered at 560 °C with a shoulder at 630 °C is observed for LSNZ6 catalyst during TPO analysis after DRM reaction at 825 °C. This suggests the presence of graphitic carbon. From these results of TPO, carbon deposition can be directly related to the activity of the catalyst. Further investigation on carbon is carried out using HRTEM analysis. Fig. 18 shows the HRTEM images of spent LSNZ6 catalysts after 100 h DRM at 800 °C and 825 °C. Clear difference in the type of carbon formed in both the samples is evident. After 800 °C DRM reaction for 100 h, LSNZ6 catalyst has traces of softer filamentous carbon which is not highly ordered. However, highly ordered graphitic carbon structures are observed in 825 °C DRM spent catalyst. These can be recognised as Multi Walled Carbon Nanotubes (MWCNT) based on their thickness (multi layered with thickness ranging from 5 nm to 15 nm). This type of carbon is generated at the metal-support interfaces and tend to separate the Ni particles from the support as they grow [50]. Even though a large quantity of MWCNT are formed in the catalyst, no deactivation was observed. Similar behaviour was observed by le Saché et al. [30]. This is explained by a reversal growth mechanism of carbon by Titus et al. [51]. Initial growth of CNTs occur at the metal-support interface of the smaller particle size Ni and separate the Ni particles from the support. However, larger amounts of CNT layers deposit around these Ni particles away from the support as they are comparatively smaller in size. The larger the particle size, the slower is the formation of CNTs around them. Thus, these CNTs grow in one direction around the smaller Ni particles and form a thick carbon shell. Particles of comparatively larger size are still accessible by the reactants at the surface. This is the reason for the high stability of the catalyst even though large quantity of high resistant MWCNTs are formed. Also, in the initial stages of the reaction, part of amorphous and polymeric carbon (soft carbon) formed on the surface are oxidised easily due to the presence of oxygen vacancies. Results of Raman spectroscopy performed on the spent catalysts after 800 °C reaction displayed no significant carbon peaks confirming the TPO result showing very little carbon formation. However, LSNZ6 catalyst which catalysed DRM reaction at 825 °C showed two significant peaks centered at ∼1340cm−1 and 1576 cm-1 corresponding to D and G bands of MWCNT respectively [52] (Fig. S8 of Supplementary Material shows Raman spectra). 4 Conclusion Effect of Ca- and Sr- substitution in Ni substituted pyrochlore catalysts on DRM activity was investigated. Pyrochlore structure formation and partial Ni substitution in the structure was confirmed from XRD. However, the presence of NiO and La-Ni perovskite phase in all the catalysts suggests the limited solubility of Ni in the pyrochlore structure. Ca- and Sr- substituted catalysts (LCNZ6 and LSNZ6) produced a highly stable La2NiZrO6 perovskite phase which is not observed in LNZ6. XRD and XANES confirmed the reduction of Ni+2 to Ni° during reduction pre-treatment process as well as during the DRM reaction. LSNZ6 catalyst showed greater activity than LCNZ6 and LNZ6 during 100 h DRM reaction at 800 °C. This appears to be due to the greater surface Ni coverage, as observed from XPS and a smaller particle size with high dispersion, as observed from XRD, SEM-EDS elemental mapping and TPR. All the catalysts showed excellent stability under these conditions with no significant sintering of the active metal. Though post reaction TPO and HRTEM showed carbon formation, there was no effect on stability of the catalysts at the conditions tested here. A comparison of coke deposited on LSNZ6 catalyst after 100 h at 800 °C and 825 °C showed the transformation of filamentous carbon to graphitic carbon (MWCNT) with the increase in reaction temperature. High methane conversion at 825 °C in LSNZ6 increased carbon accumulation resulting in the formation of carbon nanotubes (CNT). The resistance to deactivation from carbon deposition was explained using reversal growth mechanism of carbon which deactivates only a small portion of active sites, thus showing negligible effect on stability. Crystallite size increase in LSNZ6 is lesser than LNZ6 and LCNZ6 confirming its enhanced sintering resistance behaviour because of the increase in surface oxygen vacancies produced by the Sr- substitution [47]. Surface oxygen vacancy in LCNZ6 catalyst was less due to the greater surface coverage of ZrO2 shielding the vacancies. Low surface oxygen vacancy and Ni coverage on the surface restricts methane activity and enhances crystal growth on the surface in LCNZ6. coredata.dc:description: La2Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LNZ6), La1.95Ca0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LCNZ6), La1.95Sr0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-d (LSNZ6) catalysts were investigated for DRM reaction to determine the effect of Sr- and Ca- substitution at the La site in Ni substituted Lanthanum Zirconate pyrochlore. XRD confirmed the formation of the pyrochlore phase with Ni substitution. Additionally, NiO and perovskite phases of Ni were detected. XANES and XRD confirmed the reduction of Ni to active Ni0 phase in reduced and spent catalysts. LSNZ6 turned out to be the most active DRM catalyst because of the higher surface Ni content, smaller particle size and high dispersion achieved as observed from XPS, XRD, SEM-EDS elemental mapping and TPR. LSNZ6 exhibited better resistance to sintering with negligible Ni size growth compared to LCNZ6 and LNZ6. Coke formation was inevitable and LSNZ6 showed more carbon formation which suggests carbon deposition correlated directly with activity. However, it had negligible impact on the activity and stability of the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of La substitution by Sr- and Ca- in Ni substituted Lanthanum Zirconate pyrochlore catalysts for dry reforming of methane
